title: 105_hr794
content: The "Citizens' Choice Act" allows individuals to designate their income tax payments to the House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund. This Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide this option for taxpayers. Every individual with an adjusted income tax liability of $5 or more can designate $5 to the House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund. The taxpayer can choose the Democratic Party, Republican Party, or another political party as the recipient. Adjusted income tax liability is the tax liability reduced by any amount designated to the Presidential Election Campaign Fund. Joint returns are also covered. In joint returns with an adjusted income tax liability of $10 or more, each spouse can designate $5 to the House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund. The manner and time of designation follow the rules of section 6096. The House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing taxpayers to designate a portion of their income tax payments towards it. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. The House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, with accounts for each political party in congressional districts. Amounts designated by individuals are deposited into the appropriate accounts for certified House candidates. The House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund appropriates amounts designated by individuals for certified House candidates. Any remaining funds after an election are deposited into the general fund of the Treasury. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of sections for subchapter A is amended by adding a new item at the end. SEC. 4. Requirements for House of Representatives candidates who accept amounts from House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund. Amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 include new section outlining requirements for candidates receiving funds from the trust fund. The Commission certifies candidates for Congress if they meet fundraising requirements to receive payments from the House of Representatives General Election Trust Fund. Candidates must have received at least $60,000 in contributions (with no more than $1,000 from personal funds) and not provide more than $20,000 themselves. The Federal Election Commission sets limits on candidate expenditures for elections. Candidates cannot contribute more than $20,000 from personal funds or spend over $600,000 in total. However, these limits can be waived if their opponent is uncertified and has received at least $100,000 in contributions. The Federal Election Commission enforces limits on candidate expenditures, with penalties for exceeding the set limits. The Commission may audit campaign reports for compliance and impose civil penalties for violations, ranging from the amount of excess expenditure to four times that amount, except for inadvertent violations where the penalty equals the excess expenditure. The Commission shall transmit candidate names to the Secretary of the Treasury for tax code compliance. The amendment made by this section applies to elections after December 31, 1996. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON CERTAIN LOANS BY HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES GENERAL ELECTION CANDIDATES. A general election candidate for the office of Representative in Congress may not make loans totaling more than $50,000 to any campaign committee with respect to the election. Effective starting from elections after December 31, 1996.
